Change Framework developed and approved by Governing Board

description.narrative:
An organization-wide Change Framework is developed and approved by the Governing Board
The need for an organization-wide Change Framework was identified through Interpeace’s institutional review process in 2017, which identified that while Interpeace’s vision and mission were clearly articulated and understood by all of its stakeholders, the pathways to create the desired change and impact towards sustainable peace were less clear and explicit.
Responding to this assessment and recommendation, Interpeace therefore undertook to develop a comprehensive organization-wide Change Framework in 2018 which clearly sets out the different ways in which the organization pursues its overall objectives and impact goals. This will help strengthen both programming and policy as well as communications efforts of the organization.

title.narrative: Greater agility/scope in prog. dev. and mgmt. is developed

description.narrative:
Greater agility and scope in programme development and management is developed
Developing new programmes allows Interpeace to have a greater impact in fulfilling the first part of its mandate, namely to strengthen the capacities of societies to manage conflict in non-violent, non-coercive ways, by assisting national actors in their efforts to develop social and political cohesion.
The core funding by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs that Interpeace receives is an essential contribution to programme development, which is dependent upon the organization having the financial freedom to explore if its approach could add value in new contexts. This often leads to leveraging of further funds to support the newly developed programmes, thus multiplying the impact of the seed investment made possible through core funding.
Developing new programme work also contributes to attaining the overall goal of the Dutch Security and Rule of Law Division (SRoL) Theory of Change to “enhance ‘legitimate’ stability and sustainable peace in fragile contexts in order to achieve sustainable development”.

comment.narrative: Expanding the scope and reach of Interpeace programmes allows the organization to have more impact in preventing violence and building peace, notably in new and emerging conflict situations. Developing programmes in fragile countries in an agile yet carefully calibrated manner enables Interpeace to contribute to reducing violence and enhancing security, as well as increasing inclusion and resilience. This can create the conditions for sustainable development at the heart of the Security and Rule of Law Division (SRoL) Theory of Change. In 2018, Interpeace undertook programme development in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Burkina Faso, and Tunisia.

comment.narrative:
One of the key strengths of Interpeace is its ability to continuously adapt to changing contexts and emerging crises. While sustainability lies at the heart of Interpeace programmes, it is essential to regularly conduct a strategic review of programmes and adapt them to changing contexts or needs, if necessary, to ensure their continued relevance and impact.
Core funding by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs enables the organization to engage in this important exercise in a rigorous way that goes beyond what would be possible with earmarked funding alone. In 2018, programmes in Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Burundi, Rwanda, as well as the regional Great Lakes programme have undergone strategic reviews.

title.narrative: Inst. systems refined to max. accountability and efficiency

description.narrative:
Institutional systems are refined to maximize accountability, efficiency and reporting
Enhanced accountability, efficiency and reporting are key to create the transparency and trust required to engage in effective, long-term peacebuilding. We are committed to efficiency and transparency to ensure the best use of resources towards our institutional objectives and impact goals. Having modern, agile and efficient institutional systems in place, enhances Interpeace’s ability to carry out its peacebuilding work.

comment.narrative: As a leading peacebuilding organization, our IT systems need to fit our aspirations and professionalism in our programmatic and policy work. The new and updated systems ensure that our technological level is aligned with the quality of our work, with the ultimate objective of increasing our peacebuilding impact. The new IT systems allow Interpeace to communicate faster internally and externally and organize data in a more structured way, which is of crucial importance in an organization with a decentralized structure and a multitude of local partners in the field. The following IT systems have been updated or newly introduced: 1. Natural HR: A human resource management system that allows for the streamlining of HR operations in Interpeace globally, which facilitates and improves the HR management. 2. Sun Systems upgrade: Upgrade of existing financial software for improved financial management and hence transparency and accountability across the decentralized structure of the organization. 3. Internal Controls Checklist: Internally developed tool to monitor finance controls across the organization to ensure accountability. 4. Microsoft Teams: a collaboration tool that enables easier communication and tracking of internal work in the organization, particularly for teams who work across different locations. 5. ProjectConnect: A project management tool which enables, among other things, the efficient collection of data and production of the IATI reporting that helps us more effectively capture and transparently report our results.

comment.narrative:
Having a transparent and unified compensation model in place, which is aligned with each employee’s duty station market and reflects the job size and contribution value of each position at Interpeace, is key to create equity, equal pay for equal value and underpins staff motivation and performance. A well-designed compensation model also ensures that the organization is able to attract and retain the talent it requires while spending its resources effectively and transparently.
Interpeace’s compensation model required a revision to ensure its ongoing competiveness and continued relevance in a sector where the talent pool is transforming.

comment.narrative:
The staff of Interpeace are the backbone of our organization and make our peacebuilding work possible. Having satisfied, motivated and effective staff that work towards commonly agreed objectives is key to achieving our overall objectives laid down in the Change Framework. At Interpeace, Performance management is the ongoing process of planning, measuring, monitoring, and developing employee performance. Performance management focuses on continuous constructive dialogue and feedback about past performance and future development. Effective performance management is always based on a two-way exchange between the staff member and the manager:
Performance management and associated discussions are an ongoing and regular process, but once a year, the outcomes of these discussions are formally documented via the performance review process.
The performance review process can contribute to personal growth, increased employee engagement and job satisfaction. In addition, performance reviews are an integral element of the staff members’ personnel files, capturing and ensuring that institutional records are kept for future reference.

title.narrative: Policy lessons infused in hum. and sec. sector interventions

description.narrative:
Peacebuilding policy lessons have been infused in humanitarian and security sector interventions, through interventions, accompaniment and collaboration
If actors delivering humanitarian and security sector interventions adopt conflict-sensitive approaches and develop capacity to strengthen resilience to violent conflict through their programs, then these interventions will more effectively contribute to achieving sustainable peace because they will avoid unintentional exacerbation of conflict and strengthen local capacities for conflict prevention and transformation.

comment.narrative:
Engaging political leaders of donor governments in political dialogue is equally important to fulfil the second part of Interpeace’s mandate. It’s moreover a key component of Interpeace’s track 6 strategy, aiming to better align lessons learned at the field level with the political priorities and policies of governments and international organizations. When tracks 1, 2 and 3 achieve greater levels of coherence and complementarity, can our peacebuilding approaches be truly sustainable.
If the lessons shared by Interpeace are received and understood by political leaders, there is a greater chance that the policies and interventions they will shape will reflect peacebuilding principles and approaches.

title.narrative: An organization-wide Change Framework is mainstreamed

description.narrative:
The articulation of an organization-wide Change Framework allows Interpeace to work more effectively towards its institutional objective of advancing sustainable peace. It enables staff to design and implement activities utilizing clearly defined effective pathways of change to attain this objective and the organization’s three underlying impact goals: 1) Reduced Violence and Enhanced Security; 2) More Inclusion and Increased Resilience; 3) Systemic Progress in Peacebuilding Influence and Practice.
The Change Framework also informs monitoring and evaluation efforts to enable Interpeace to more effectively track and report on the impacts it is collectively achieving as an organization. This comes at a time when the organization is also increasing its capacity to influence international policy with insights drawn from programming.

comment.narrative:
Interpeace developed an organization-wide change framework through a participatory process in 2018. As a first step towards ensuring all of the organization’s programmes and initiatives are designed and implemented in pursuit of the identified institutional objectives and impact goals, a process was subsequently undertaken to closely familiarize all staff with the Change Framework and its implications for their work.
The framework is reflected in the 2019 workplan for the organization. The framework in place now also allows Interpeace to speak with one voice and more effectively contribute to the shared goal of sustainable peace.
